abstract.p: Prof Elisha P Renne letter comments on August 20 article on debt relief for Nigeria

''Against Odds, Nigeria Bets on Reform'' (front page, Aug. 20) describes the difficult conditions under which most Nigerians live and the difficult political situation faced by the newly elected president, Olusegun Obasanjo. These topics were widely discussed in Nigeria during my stay there last month.

Not mentioned in the article was President Obasanjo's active lobbying of the Group of 8 industrialized countries for debt cancellation. Nigeria has a debt of $32 billion; 35 percent of its yearly foreign exchange earnings go to service this debt. Even though Nigeria has substantial oil wealth, these large payments have hurt the government's ability to restore the country's infrastructure.
If the United States and other countries are serious about supporting democracy in Nigeria, they should devise a plan for debt cancellation or other debt relief.
ELISHA P. RENNE Ann Arbor, Mich., Aug. 21, 2000
The writer is an assistant professor of anthropology, University of Michigan.
